These are bitter times, said old Roger
Norton, as he paced back and forward on the
little green, before his rude cabin, smoking
his pipe with a vehemence which to the in
dwelers of that homely hut, gave sure and
fearful note that something of alarming i'm
port was working in his bosom The good
dame, who had been engaged industriousy
at the wheel, rose and set it aside, disquiet-
ed by the omen, and beautiful girl Came
to the broken and decayed window, and
looked out with trembling anxiety towards
the west The sun was gliding gently down
behind appalling masses of thunder clouds,
which were piled up from the horizon, high
in the mellow bosom of the heavens, and
from the direction of the winds threatened
tempest OF no ordinary magnitude. The
shadows of approaching night were already
fast changing the green mantle of the thick
forest to one of funeral gloom, and the start
ling screeeh Of the grey owl fell at inter
walls on the ear of watchtul anxiety.


At the cottage all was silent-hope and
fear alternately lighted or shaded each
changing brow--as the distant echoes seem
ed to come laden with the tramp of horse
men, or the cool dew of evening fell silent
on the diving breeze. At length flash was
seen in the thickness of the forest and
sound like the report of distant rifle pealed
along the broken hillocks that bounded the
valley brook. The aged dame with her
young daughter-n-law and two lovely chill
slren crowded the door in an instant, and old
Roger, putting hispipe hastily into his pock-
ct, turned to them, and placed his finger on
his lips, as in momentary thought. "There
has been blood spilled on the lowlands to-
day." said he, "and God knows which par
ty is the victor; we must bear our fate with
patient suferance; we have put up. our u
nited prayers for George, and heaven will
do right; it becomes us in times like these
to use all due precauton in warding the
blow from our own heads The ladies un-
derstood him, and though Eliza wrung her
hands and struggled deeply with her feel
ings, when the danger to which her George
was exposed, was made known to her, and
the thought that he was perhaps now a
corpse weltcring in his blood rushed across
her breast, yet they all went quietly in, and
assumed such employment as was best CAL
culated to conceal the interest they took in
the passing scenes of war aud bloodshed a
round them.


Situated as they were, in country tra-
versed successfully by the British and lndi-
ans, secured by the American Foragers, of
corps of which old Norton's only son was
the commander; they had hitherto conceal
THE FORAGGRS. S.

The observance of the Sabbath claims at
all times the attention not only OF the lovers
OF ofreliglon, but of the friends of good order,
and public virtue. We are not disposed to
think that it is falling into neglect, but there
is certainly lamentable apathy among a.
vowed christians in regard to the best mode
OF employing the day, as we'll as visible
PROCLAMATION of it by the irreigious. The a.
buse OF season of rest by deyoting it to
pleasure, and the contempt thrown upon it
by those who spend the first day of the week
IN open sloth or in secret business, merit a
seyerer reproof than can be administered
through the columns OF weekly paper.
We would suggest few hints to those who
profess to regard the Sabbath as holy time,
yet are far from spending it in "the beauty
Of holiness'


he Sabbath is begun wrong, or rather its
IoniM encement is postponed as long as pos
siole. We know no reason that justites a
CHRISTIAN in giving an hour to sleep ON SUM-
uay morning, which he would have spent in
ACTIVE preparation Tor his business, if 1t had
peen the morning of week day. No one
WIN pretend that he has right to make ex-
uaofdlnary exertions, and incur unusual fa-
usne on Saturday, because he can lie in bed
~ long as he pleases the next morning. Yet
I.seems to be the opinion of very many per-
sol's, that they have this right, or what is still
worse, that they are at liberty to indulge
themselves in sleep on Sabbath mornings,
"nether they have, or have not been unusu-
any occupied on the preceding day. The
nhractice IN many religious families, both in
os ose city and country, is, to rise an hour and
o.u o.seh TWO hours later on Sunday than any
,h;N amer morning. We need not stop to argue
h. nus Pelnt with religsus men; the habit has
ss eu formed, we presume, without thinking
~ Ns criminality, and it will be sufficient to
a. .nose who continue In it, where they


1oX naEnlsslQp to waste more time on
TEfE MONITOR.
TEE SABBATH.

Whenever | want to be cXcuisitely hap
py, call to my recollections the passionate
emotions which tlrob)ed in the bosom when
it counted about eighteen summer suns,---
The age of romance, fancy and imagination
too often ceases at tfive-andtwenty, but there
is no pleasure SO exquisite as the first sensa-
tions which female lovelness excltes in the
bosom of romantic youth. 1t approaches
to the ccstacy of higher exstence.-Ihe
objects of his thoughts seen afar off is sutfl-
cient to put hin on flame. The very green
swarl which she treads acquires the char
acter of holy ground 1.-The house in which
She resides kindles the flame of DEVOTION
But how soon all these fine feelings subsde
in the bosom of man. The flame of love, as
it is called, is only of short duration in tho
breast of the male sex. 1t glows, and flames,
and burns for few short years on both sides
of twenty, and then sinks down forever. The
heart of woman is different. Love and affec,
tion are the absorbents of her whole exls-
tence. Man has hundred other objects.
YOUTHFUL LIFE.

My heart is like the falling hearth


Now by my side
One by one its burst of fame


Have burnt and died.
There are none to watch the sinking blaze,
And none to care,
Or lfit kndle into strength.


Or waste i'll air.
My fate is as yon faded wreath


of summer fowers;
They've spent their store of fragrant health
On sunny hours,
Which recked them not, which needed not
When they were dead
Other flowers, unwarn'd by them,
Will spring instead.
And my own heart is as the lutte
now am waking;
Wound to otoo fine and high pitch
They both are breaking.
And of their song what memory


Will stav behind'
An echo, like passing thought,


Upon the wind.
Silence, forgetfulness, and rust,
Lutte, are for thee;
And such my lott neglect, the grave,
These are for me.
SONG.

The following account of the circumstan~
ces which gave rise to the strange custom OF
throwing open the gates of Howth castle, at
the first toll of the dinner bell, has been col
lected in two places, at opposite extremities
of Ireland; tradition supplying in the one,
what it had left wanting in the other: A.
bout the middle of the sixth century, Grana
Waillia, or Grace O'Maley, exercised the
same power over the 365 islands of Clew
Bay, which her ancestors had, at an earlier
period, over all Ireland. She possessed a
manly mind, and spirit well adapted for the
wild scene in which she lived, and the rude
men whom she governed-had caused much
bloodshctl, and done many fearful deed ON
sea and land; but "none are all evil,o and
she also possessed an excess Of high and gem
erous feeling, which seldom fails, with pos
teritY at least, to cover q multitude of sins


The ruins of her castle may yet be seen-a
huge mass of gray stone, looking tow ards the
main land, from the tlesoate island of ST.
Clare, which is at the extremity of the clus.
ter, and apparently formed forn 10 other pur-
pose than t. break the force of the Atlantic
as it rolls into Clew Bay. There was scarce.
ly a town or village along the western coast,
which had not been at one time or other, Wis.
tied and plundered in the course of her pi-
ratical excur sions, and as the evil was Sc,
verely felt so was the outciy proportionablv
great. Still there was no chance of redress.
except from direct appeal from the sove-
reign, as she was ali-pow werful at sea, an,,
lived on the best terms of intelligence with
Richard Bourke, Fisconnt ard Governor g.
GRACE O'yN ALLEY.
AN IRISH TRADITIONAL STORY.

Ont lie pire destin;

servius Sulpicius, endeavoring to console
Cicero for the loss of his daughter, thus adj
dressed him: "On my return from Asia
having left Egina on my way to Megara, my
eve rested OH the objects which sulrouned
me-Megara was behind me; Pir@us lay or
nv right, and Corinth on my left. How ma
BURIAL OF A YOUNG LADY.

head of the bed, holding the hand OF her
daughter--would have surprised me, l had
not seen that it was produced by their con-
fidence in young physician, in Titus wig,
curled with the utmost care, who assured
them (admiring himself in the mirror while
he spoke, and flirting, with the end Of his
finger, the remains of pinch of snuff, which
had fallen on the frll of his shirt,) that the
quickness was entirely owing to febrile
movement induced by the paroxysm of the
evening before. / took my leave, feeling
less confidence in the sounding words of the
doctor, than in the prudence of the father,
and the youth of the patient


After quitting this scene, business called
me for few days into the country. On my
return home my porter brought me the let
tiers which had arrived for me during my
absence, amongst these was one Of larger
dimensions than the others; opened it hast
lily, and, inscribed on a grey satin paper
bordered with mournful vignettes, repre-
senting the attributes OF death, read the
words, .Astend the funeral of Robertine."
threw myself into carriage, and on arr
irving at the Hotel de Vilarmont, found the
fatal draperies of death already hung around.
Itraversed the deserted apartments; has
tened to the closet of Monsieur de Vilar-
mont, which found him pacing with length-
ened strides. He saw me, and threw him
self into my arms. without uttering single
word. The silent agony of struggle between
manly fortitute and overwhelming grief, re-
pulsed all those established consultations Of
which Indifference is always SO prodgal.--
Come" said he, after few moments si-
lence Il have need ofyour assistance to force
my wife to quit this house." What
frightful spectacle Altered itself to my eyes
in this unfortunate mother Never have
seen grief under such an agonizing appear
ance. On her knees at the door of her
daughters chamber, which force alone pre-
vented her from entering. She wept not;
her blood shot eyes were dry, fixed, and va
cant, "Robertine, my child" were the only
words which escaped her lips. !, myself,
eiesignedly, resounded this loved name in
her ear, her tears began to flow again; her
strength failed, she tainted away; and we
took advantage of this cruel moment, to car
ry her through the garden to the carriage,
into which her husband accompanied her,
| in order to conduct her to the house of
her father. Ireturned into the parlour, where
all the friends ofthe family were assembled in
gloomy silence, preparatory to the funeral
ceremony. The open windows gave us
view of The great gate of the hotel, where
was the coffin, covered with white silver
tringed drapery and surrounded by twenty
Young girls, clothed in white, with their
I faces covered by long wells, but whose sobs
and prayers were audible even to our ears.
| The master of the ceremonies now came to
acquaint US that all was ready. The body
had been placed upon car, draperied like
the coffin, OIL which were mounted four
Young girs Who held the corners of the
mortuary pail. and who handed to their
companions the strings of silver with which
the coffin was surrounded. The relations,
| in manner buried under their cloaks of
Grape, followed on foot, and the numerous
friends Of the family, in mourning coaches.
prolonged the procession, which was closed
by the servants of the house, clothed in
| black. Our first stoppage was at the church
of the Mathurins where the last Offices ofre-
! ligion were celebrated; after which we pro
cecded, in the same order to the cemetry of
| Mont Martre, where, near the tomb where
sleep the ashes of the Poet of the Seasons,
st. Lambert, the green turf had been hol-
lowed, to receive the remains of charming
being, whom heaven appeared to have shown
to us for few short moments, only to leave
an eternal regret for her loss.


Robertne had no name to transmit to pos
teritv-her memory belongs exclusively to
her disconsolate parents, and for that reason
they have been content to engrave on the
stone which conceals her forever from their
view, the lines of Malherbes, which I have
cited i'll the commencement of this article.
"lom in world, where flowers of farest hue
First fade away;


Herself a rose, she lived, as roses do


But tora day.

1.-THE Lords day than common days, or to
take portion of time from the period pc
culiarly consecrated to religious duties, to
compensate for an improper devotion of
hours to worldly business.


The effect Of this custom of family, is
however worthy of suggestion. Children do
not easily learn to stupify their faculties in
sleep for two or three hours after the sun has
risen, and after they wake on the Sabbath,
finding those who should be ready to restrain
aud instruct them, still held by slumber,
they pass those hours in noise or mischief
or at least uneasiness. In one part OF the
house is unlawful repose, and in another
part confusion, and the consequence is that
the day, begun wrong, is kept and ended
wrong, and children grow up with dislike
of that season, the return of which they
should be taught to welcome. They learn
indeed to follow the example oftheir parents,
and drown their love of activity in sleep,
and are thus led in sinful habit which they
continue through life, without perhaps feel


ing single doubt of its propriety. Their
father did so, why should not theys Let
parents consider this.

~, Halian Peasant Indicating Looe Lettc'
Come, thou old, unloving scribe,
Thou shalt have noble bribc:
choose it-medal, coin, or gem,
Topaz ring, or coral stem
Take thy pen and tell my love,
How. to earth and heaven above,
How, to every sainted maid,
Ihaye watch'tl, and wept and pray'd,
O'er him, with their wings to stoop,
Where he steers his bold chaloupci
O'er him, in the sullcn night,
When the storm is in its might,
O'er him, i'll the fearful day,
When the lance and sabre play,
And the soldiers hour is lnol'd,
Stretched upon the sangnine mo.d,
Him on surge, or him On steea,
Still to spare, and sil. to Speed
Listen no~i--'I'is vain, lis v,l,A
What can read the burning brAin,
What can tell the thousandth part
of the agonies heart,
Secrets that the spirit keeps,
Thoughts on which it wakes and weeps;
To the mortal ear unknown,
Kept for night and heaven alone!
Old man, tell him of the tale
Written in this cheek so pale
Wild and often has the tear,
Wash'd the rose that once was there's
Tell him of my heavy sigh,
Deep as from the lips that die,
Of my eyes decaying beam,
Life departing like stream.
Tell him of my weary day,
Bid him, Oh! do all but stay:
he would not see my tomb,
Bid him come, and--swiftly come!

Were we not proud ourselves. we should
seldom complain of the pride of others.


In our reprehensions, pride has greater
share than good nature. We reprove not so
much in order to correct, as to intimate that
we hold ourselves free from such faiings.


Nothing is more rare than true good ma
ture. Many who imagine they possess it.,
naYe nothing more than a politeness and
case,


The rcsolute alone can be truly good ma
tured; those who commonly seem to be So,
are weak, and arc easily sourcd.


VIC seldom praise those heartily who
seem rot to admire rs,


When we seem to blaine ourselves, we
mean only 20 e.Stor. praise.


BY taking revenge man IS bnt even with
his enemy: but in passing it o1cr, he is snpe-
rior.

the vlgilant but cautious measures of George
Norton insured them protection from the A.
mercans.


The report that had reused them from their
twilight revery, died away, but the sound
of coming troopers succeeded after a short
interval, and in a few minutes their tossing
plumes were seen dancing along the white
fences, and approaching the lonely cottage.
The old man threw down the bars that led
into the yard, and began to throw water in
to the long trough to supply their horses,
trembling all the while in suspense, whether
he was about to receive his bosom child, or
smooth his brow to smiling welcome of
men whose hands, for aught he knew,


might be weltering in his sons blood. The
| suspense was of momentary duration, the
first who approached him wore the uniform
of Briton, and his heart sunk within him
as he reached out his withered hand to
welcome him and assisted him in dismount-
ing.


! BY this time the whole corps was up, and
Roger recognized several of his old guests
among .hem. Some wounded soldiers were
carried to the barn, aud the officers, as soon
as their arrangements were completed with
out, accepted the apparently cordial invita-
! ton of the host to share the comforts of the


house; meantime, the table was spread and


decorated with the best the humble circum-
stances of the owner could afford. The Of
/ hcers were eight in number, all hardy, SOL
1 derly looking men, and, as they threw off


their heavy swords and caps, and crowded


round the hospitabe table, they resumed
the conversation it seemed they had lett Oft


when they first came up. "Well,' said the
Major, Il believe we determined upon all
| but the time and place of execution. -
"And that" replied sturdy fellow, on the
| other side, "s easily arranged; what say YOU


to farmer Norton's barn yard, and eight in
the morning. just by way of desert, besides,
| we shall save the rascal's break fast for some


better fellow" agreed. agreed, +" said they
all. The arrangements were thus made for
| the execution Of the prisoner, over hearty
meal and, when finished. a messenger was
despatched to inform him of his fate and bid


him prepare for it.


However i'll the members Of this little
family concealed their anxiety, in the mean
time, their agitation was not discovcred.--
The old man pretended to busy himself to
such degree as not to take notice of any
thing that passed, and Eliza left the room
determined to ascertain the worst, as the
suspense in which these proceedings involv-
cd her, was more cruel than the bitterest
reality could be. She soon found her saddest
fears were realized. Her husband was the
prisoner in whose blood they were to riot on
the morrow He was already wounded,
and was lying on some straw in bar
rack near the house, guarded by file OF
solders.


10 accomplish his rescue was now the de-
termined purpose OF her soul, though she
should sell her life in the attempt. She to K
her measures accordingly. She observed
the officer, who most resembled her in size,
and whose voice and manner she could easily
initiate and took measures to have him 'odg-
ed apart from his companions in little cor
ner room to which she could gain ready ac-
cess. She ascertained what was the coun-
tersgn, and having matured her design, re-
tired unsupported


At the dead hour OF the night, when all
was silent AS the grave, save now and then
the dull tramp of the sentinels was heard,
she stole into the young officers room and
carried off his clothes and sword Appar
elled i'll these, she passed the guard unsus-
pected, and penetrated into the prison of
her beloved and suffering husband. To ban
ish every shade of suspicion from the guard,
which walked around the barrack, assuming
the tone Of the officer she initiated, she ac-
costed the PROSTATE victim of revenge with
opprobious epi,hets, and asked him if his
neck was ready for the haltar-at the same
time endeavoring to make him understand
who she was. This unexpected intrusion
reused up the heroic American; he had re-
ceived his sentence, and had resolved to
bear it as soldier ought, for his wounds for
bid the hope of escape. But when he heard
the voice which too exactly initiated that of
his bitterest foe, his soul kindled to fame.
and sprnging from the ground he seized the
hilt of the sword which faint CLEAN of
moonlight revealed before him, drew it like
lightning from its scabbard, and plunged it
through Eiza's heart. She shrieked and
feil--while he, with one stroke, severing the
cords that bound him, leaped into the midst
of the guard, and three of them fell before
him ere his arm was paralyzed by death.
shot in the head killed him on the spot.


The camp was all alarm. A general rush
to the scene of blood succeeded, and the
cause was revealed. Even the wretches
who prosecuted theire discriminating warfare
with SO little mercy, wept over the heart
rending scene, and the aged parents were
left unmoested. The corpses were inferred
beneath green tree in the border of the
forest together, and the willow tree which
was planted by the grave, now spreads its
broad top wide over the unlettcred tomb
stone.

FEBRUARY 22. le27

ceived that a man should suffer himself to
be overcome by the loss of child" These
reflections, however just-however philo-
sophical-tlid not console the father of Tul
liza; because, there are sorrows over which
reason has no power, and tears which time
alone can dry.


During my career of life, I have frequent
ly seen my companions fall by my side-my
brothers in arms-whose loss l have most
deeply deplored; but, in recalling to my
mind those ideas of glory, that hereditary
fame, which SO peculiarly endears the mem
cries of heroes who have fallen in the field of
honour, and rejecting that nothing was left
for me, but an infirm old age, and an obscure
grave, ! have frequently been tempted to
envy those whose names are immortalized
by their very deaths Every day takes from
me some old friend-some companion, of an
age equally advanced with myself regret
them, but without murmuring, in the words
of Montague, their lamp of life had burnt
to the socket; death is the immediate con-
sequence of protracted old age. But, when
young girl, just entering the portals of life
for whom heaven appears to have III store
a long series of happy years, on whom ma
ture has lavished all her most precious gifts


and whom birth and fortune have surround


ed with their most brilliant delusions--when


a being such as this is torn from the EN-.
braces of her mother, the hopes of her family,
and the expectations OF love, there is i'll this
cruel decree of fate, a kind of subvcrsion Of
the general laws of natlre--an assembage
OF contradictory circumstances, ldeaz and


cXpres ssions at which the senses sicken, and
the hearts break. Such is the event to which


| have alluded in the title of this article, and
ofwhch, during this short depression, have
rot lost sight.


/ Robertne de Nilarmont was the daughter
ofa brave companion in arms of the gallant


De Sufireen, who by twenty years nf glori-


GUS toll, had acquired an undoubted right to
enjoy in the bosom of his family, an ample
patrimonial estate, to which he has added lit


tle,or nothing by his services. He still rcckon-
ed among hisimpertlve duties, that of educat-


ing his son for the service of his country, and
ofbringing up his daughtcrto become the re-


ward of some young soldier, who, by
his name, his rank, and his merit should
show himself worthy OF such recompcnse.-
! | had known NJ. de Vilarmont in the East
| Indies.-A1uch Younger than ME, his father
had consigned him to my care; as to that of
a Mentor, and our relations of friendship
have never since been interrupted. 1t is
two years since accompanied him to Roch


etort, when he went thither to enter his son
as a midshipman, on the quarter deck of
vessel which he had himself commanded,
and at whose masthead the grandfather of
the young man had thirty years before,
! hosted the flag of vice-admiral. This reg
ular descent of glory, was good omen. and
/ accordingly our young Leon, as a reward
for gallant action, has already received the
decoration of the brave.


/ r., L.
reached her fifteenth year. Educated with
/ the tenderest care, under the eye of the
most af1'ectionate of mothers, she was alrea-


ly remarked as the model Of every rersec-
ton. 1t was the first season that the young
Robertine had appeared in the world; and all
eyes were turned upon her, and her delight


ed mother enjoyed, with too much con-
/ fidence. (why may | not say with too much
pride') the brilliant success which her
daughter met with at all concerts and balls,
of which she formed at once the principal
object ard the chief ornament. The birth


day of Mademoisel!c de Vlarnnnt had been
celebrated by brillilnt tete at the house of
her maternal grandfather, at which she had
made the deepest impression by the charms
Of her person, and the proofs which she had
given of the superiority Of her talents, which
her interesting modestv set off with double
I, splendour. Monsieurde Niarmont had been
prevented from accompanying the ladies,
whom he had, therefore entrusted to my
care; and during the whole continuance of
the ball, which encroached far into the morn
| ing, had ofliciated as gentleman N waiting
on the fair Robertine; I held her fan and her
iandk erchef while she danced; | led her
back to her place, and took particular care
to cover her with her shawl, as soon as the
country dance was concluded. ] was under
the same charm which had enchanted every
one around me. How suddenly and how
dreadfully was it to be dispelled 1t was
O'Clock when the party broke up-Rober-
tine had danced in the last set--her mother
wished that she should sit down little while
to cool herself; but with shawl, wrapping
cloak lined with fur, and a well closed car
riage, what danger, could possibly be ap
prehendetls On our going down stairs, the
coachmau was not with his horses; and
while the servants went in search of him,
we had to wait some minutes in freezing
hall, Gan inconvenience very general in Paris.
and from which even her palaces are not ex-
empt) Atlast the carriage drove up, Mad
anne de Nilarmont set me down at home, and
the lovely Robertine, in bidding me good
night, added, that she could not do without.
me, and that she retained me as her escort
to all the balls the next season. "lf am
alive" answered |, "but, next year is

THE FORAGGRS. S.

These are bitter times, said old Roger
Norton, as he paced back and forward on the
little green, before his rude cabin, smoking
his pipe with a vehemence which to the in
dwelers of that homely hut, gave sure and
fearful note that something of alarming i'm
port was working in his bosom The good
dame, who had been engaged industriousy
at the wheel, rose and set it aside, disquiet-
ed by the omen, and beautiful girl Came
to the broken and decayed window, and
looked out with trembling anxiety towards
the west The sun was gliding gently down
behind appalling masses of thunder clouds,
which were piled up from the horizon, high
in the mellow bosom of the heavens, and
from the direction of the winds threatened
tempest OF no ordinary magnitude. The
shadows of approaching night were already
fast changing the green mantle of the thick
forest to one of funeral gloom, and the start
ling screeeh Of the grey owl fell at inter
walls on the ear of watchtul anxiety.


At the cottage all was silent-hope and
fear alternately lighted or shaded each
changing brow--as the distant echoes seem
ed to come laden with the tramp of horse
men, or the cool dew of evening fell silent
on the diving breeze. At length flash was
seen in the thickness of the forest and
sound like the report of distant rifle pealed
along the broken hillocks that bounded the
valley brook. The aged dame with her
young daughter-n-law and two lovely chill
slren crowded the door in an instant, and old
Roger, putting hispipe hastily into his pock-
ct, turned to them, and placed his finger on
his lips, as in momentary thought. "There
has been blood spilled on the lowlands to-
day." said he, "and God knows which par
ty is the victor; we must bear our fate with
patient suferance; we have put up. our u
nited prayers for George, and heaven will
do right; it becomes us in times like these
to use all due precauton in warding the
blow from our own heads The ladies un-
derstood him, and though Eliza wrung her
hands and struggled deeply with her feel
ings, when the danger to which her George
was exposed, was made known to her, and
the thought that he was perhaps now a
corpse weltcring in his blood rushed across
her breast, yet they all went quietly in, and
assumed such employment as was best CAL
culated to conceal the interest they took in
the passing scenes of war aud bloodshed a
round them.


Situated as they were, in country tra-
versed successfully by the British and lndi-
ans, secured by the American Foragers, of
corps of which old Norton's only son was
the commander; they had hitherto conceal

full articles.headline:
TEfE MONITOR.

TEE SABBATH.
full articles.article:
The observance of the Sabbath claims at
all times the attention not only OF the lovers
OF ofreliglon, but of the friends of good order,
and public virtue. We are not disposed to
think that it is falling into neglect, but there
is certainly lamentable apathy among a.
vowed christians in regard to the best mode
OF employing the day, as we'll as visible
PROCLAMATION of it by the irreigious. The a.
buse OF season of rest by deyoting it to
pleasure, and the contempt thrown upon it
by those who spend the first day of the week
IN open sloth or in secret business, merit a
seyerer reproof than can be administered
through the columns OF weekly paper.
We would suggest few hints to those who
profess to regard the Sabbath as holy time,
yet are far from spending it in "the beauty
Of holiness'


he Sabbath is begun wrong, or rather its
IoniM encement is postponed as long as pos
siole. We know no reason that justites a
CHRISTIAN in giving an hour to sleep ON SUM-
uay morning, which he would have spent in
ACTIVE preparation Tor his business, if 1t had
peen the morning of week day. No one
WIN pretend that he has right to make ex-
uaofdlnary exertions, and incur unusual fa-
usne on Saturday, because he can lie in bed
~ long as he pleases the next morning. Yet
I.seems to be the opinion of very many per-
sol's, that they have this right, or what is still
worse, that they are at liberty to indulge
themselves in sleep on Sabbath mornings,
"nether they have, or have not been unusu-
any occupied on the preceding day. The
nhractice IN many religious families, both in
os ose city and country, is, to rise an hour and
o.u o.seh TWO hours later on Sunday than any
,h;N amer morning. We need not stop to argue
h. nus Pelnt with religsus men; the habit has
ss eu formed, we presume, without thinking
~ Ns criminality, and it will be sufficient to
a. .nose who continue In it, where they


1oX naEnlsslQp to waste more time on

full articles.headline: YOUTHFUL LIFE.
full articles.article:
Whenever | want to be cXcuisitely hap
py, call to my recollections the passionate
emotions which tlrob)ed in the bosom when
it counted about eighteen summer suns,---
The age of romance, fancy and imagination
too often ceases at tfive-andtwenty, but there
is no pleasure SO exquisite as the first sensa-
tions which female lovelness excltes in the
bosom of romantic youth. 1t approaches
to the ccstacy of higher exstence.-Ihe
objects of his thoughts seen afar off is sutfl-
cient to put hin on flame. The very green
swarl which she treads acquires the char
acter of holy ground 1.-The house in which
She resides kindles the flame of DEVOTION
But how soon all these fine feelings subsde
in the bosom of man. The flame of love, as
it is called, is only of short duration in tho
breast of the male sex. 1t glows, and flames,
and burns for few short years on both sides
of twenty, and then sinks down forever. The
heart of woman is different. Love and affec,
tion are the absorbents of her whole exls-
tence. Man has hundred other objects.

full articles.headline: SONG.
full articles.article:
My heart is like the falling hearth


Now by my side
One by one its burst of fame


Have burnt and died.
There are none to watch the sinking blaze,
And none to care,
Or lfit kndle into strength.


Or waste i'll air.
My fate is as yon faded wreath


of summer fowers;
They've spent their store of fragrant health
On sunny hours,
Which recked them not, which needed not
When they were dead
Other flowers, unwarn'd by them,
Will spring instead.
And my own heart is as the lutte
now am waking;
Wound to otoo fine and high pitch
They both are breaking.
And of their song what memory


Will stav behind'
An echo, like passing thought,


Upon the wind.
Silence, forgetfulness, and rust,
Lutte, are for thee;
And such my lott neglect, the grave,
These are for me.

full articles.headline: GRACE O'yN ALLEY.
full articles.article:
The following account of the circumstan~
ces which gave rise to the strange custom OF
throwing open the gates of Howth castle, at
the first toll of the dinner bell, has been col
lected in two places, at opposite extremities
of Ireland; tradition supplying in the one,
what it had left wanting in the other: A.
bout the middle of the sixth century, Grana
Waillia, or Grace O'Maley, exercised the
same power over the 365 islands of Clew
Bay, which her ancestors had, at an earlier
period, over all Ireland. She possessed a
manly mind, and spirit well adapted for the
wild scene in which she lived, and the rude
men whom she governed-had caused much
bloodshctl, and done many fearful deed ON
sea and land; but "none are all evil,o and
she also possessed an excess Of high and gem
erous feeling, which seldom fails, with pos
teritY at least, to cover q multitude of sins


The ruins of her castle may yet be seen-a
huge mass of gray stone, looking tow ards the
main land, from the tlesoate island of ST.
Clare, which is at the extremity of the clus.
ter, and apparently formed forn 10 other pur-
pose than t. break the force of the Atlantic
as it rolls into Clew Bay. There was scarce.
ly a town or village along the western coast,
which had not been at one time or other, Wis.
tied and plundered in the course of her pi-
ratical excur sions, and as the evil was Sc,
verely felt so was the outciy proportionablv
great. Still there was no chance of redress.
except from direct appeal from the sove-
reign, as she was ali-pow werful at sea, an,,
lived on the best terms of intelligence with
Richard Bourke, Fisconnt ard Governor g.

full articles.headline: BURIAL OF A YOUNG LADY.
full articles.article:
(From I.'Hermite de la Chausee D'Antin.)
ssElle etoit de ce monde ou les plus belle chooses


Ont lie pire destin;


Et rose, ellie yecu, ceque vivent les roses
L'espace dun matin."


servius Sulpicius, endeavoring to console
Cicero for the loss of his daughter, thus adj
dressed him: "On my return from Asia
having left Egina on my way to Megara, my
eve rested OH the objects which sulrouned
me-Megara was behind me; Pir@us lay or
nv right, and Corinth on my left. How ma

head of the bed, holding the hand OF her
daughter--would have surprised me, l had
not seen that it was produced by their con-
fidence in young physician, in Titus wig,
curled with the utmost care, who assured
them (admiring himself in the mirror while
he spoke, and flirting, with the end Of his
finger, the remains of pinch of snuff, which
had fallen on the frll of his shirt,) that the
quickness was entirely owing to febrile
movement induced by the paroxysm of the
evening before. / took my leave, feeling
less confidence in the sounding words of the
doctor, than in the prudence of the father,
and the youth of the patient


After quitting this scene, business called
me for few days into the country. On my
return home my porter brought me the let
tiers which had arrived for me during my
absence, amongst these was one Of larger
dimensions than the others; opened it hast
lily, and, inscribed on a grey satin paper
bordered with mournful vignettes, repre-
senting the attributes OF death, read the
words, .Astend the funeral of Robertine."
threw myself into carriage, and on arr
irving at the Hotel de Vilarmont, found the
fatal draperies of death already hung around.
Itraversed the deserted apartments; has
tened to the closet of Monsieur de Vilar-
mont, which found him pacing with length-
ened strides. He saw me, and threw him
self into my arms. without uttering single
word. The silent agony of struggle between
manly fortitute and overwhelming grief, re-
pulsed all those established consultations Of
which Indifference is always SO prodgal.--
Come" said he, after few moments si-
lence Il have need ofyour assistance to force
my wife to quit this house." What
frightful spectacle Altered itself to my eyes
in this unfortunate mother Never have
seen grief under such an agonizing appear
ance. On her knees at the door of her
daughters chamber, which force alone pre-
vented her from entering. She wept not;
her blood shot eyes were dry, fixed, and va
cant, "Robertine, my child" were the only
words which escaped her lips. !, myself,
eiesignedly, resounded this loved name in
her ear, her tears began to flow again; her
strength failed, she tainted away; and we
took advantage of this cruel moment, to car
ry her through the garden to the carriage,
into which her husband accompanied her,
| in order to conduct her to the house of
her father. Ireturned into the parlour, where
all the friends ofthe family were assembled in
gloomy silence, preparatory to the funeral
ceremony. The open windows gave us
view of The great gate of the hotel, where
was the coffin, covered with white silver
tringed drapery and surrounded by twenty
Young girls, clothed in white, with their
I faces covered by long wells, but whose sobs
and prayers were audible even to our ears.
| The master of the ceremonies now came to
acquaint US that all was ready. The body
had been placed upon car, draperied like
the coffin, OIL which were mounted four
Young girs Who held the corners of the
mortuary pail. and who handed to their
companions the strings of silver with which
the coffin was surrounded. The relations,
| in manner buried under their cloaks of
Grape, followed on foot, and the numerous
friends Of the family, in mourning coaches.
prolonged the procession, which was closed
by the servants of the house, clothed in
| black. Our first stoppage was at the church
of the Mathurins where the last Offices ofre-
! ligion were celebrated; after which we pro
cecded, in the same order to the cemetry of
| Mont Martre, where, near the tomb where
sleep the ashes of the Poet of the Seasons,
st. Lambert, the green turf had been hol-
lowed, to receive the remains of charming
being, whom heaven appeared to have shown
to us for few short moments, only to leave
an eternal regret for her loss.


Robertne had no name to transmit to pos
teritv-her memory belongs exclusively to
her disconsolate parents, and for that reason
they have been content to engrave on the
stone which conceals her forever from their
view, the lines of Malherbes, which I have
cited i'll the commencement of this article.
"lom in world, where flowers of farest hue
First fade away;


Herself a rose, she lived, as roses do


But tora day.

1.-THE Lords day than common days, or to
take portion of time from the period pc
culiarly consecrated to religious duties, to
compensate for an improper devotion of
hours to worldly business.


The effect Of this custom of family, is
however worthy of suggestion. Children do
not easily learn to stupify their faculties in
sleep for two or three hours after the sun has
risen, and after they wake on the Sabbath,
finding those who should be ready to restrain
aud instruct them, still held by slumber,
they pass those hours in noise or mischief
or at least uneasiness. In one part OF the
house is unlawful repose, and in another
part confusion, and the consequence is that
the day, begun wrong, is kept and ended
wrong, and children grow up with dislike
of that season, the return of which they
should be taught to welcome. They learn
indeed to follow the example oftheir parents,
and drown their love of activity in sleep,
and are thus led in sinful habit which they
continue through life, without perhaps feel


ing single doubt of its propriety. Their
father did so, why should not theys Let
parents consider this.

full articles.headline: PQ-EIASYa .
full articles.article:
~, Halian Peasant Indicating Looe Lettc'
Come, thou old, unloving scribe,
Thou shalt have noble bribc:
choose it-medal, coin, or gem,
Topaz ring, or coral stem
Take thy pen and tell my love,
How. to earth and heaven above,
How, to every sainted maid,
Ihaye watch'tl, and wept and pray'd,
O'er him, with their wings to stoop,
Where he steers his bold chaloupci
O'er him, in the sullcn night,
When the storm is in its might,
O'er him, i'll the fearful day,
When the lance and sabre play,
And the soldiers hour is lnol'd,
Stretched upon the sangnine mo.d,
Him on surge, or him On steea,
Still to spare, and sil. to Speed
Listen no~i--'I'is vain, lis v,l,A
What can read the burning brAin,
What can tell the thousandth part
of the agonies heart,
Secrets that the spirit keeps,
Thoughts on which it wakes and weeps;
To the mortal ear unknown,
Kept for night and heaven alone!
Old man, tell him of the tale
Written in this cheek so pale
Wild and often has the tear,
Wash'd the rose that once was there's
Tell him of my heavy sigh,
Deep as from the lips that die,
Of my eyes decaying beam,
Life departing like stream.
Tell him of my weary day,
Bid him, Oh! do all but stay:
he would not see my tomb,
Bid him come, and--swiftly come!

Were we not proud ourselves. we should
seldom complain of the pride of others.


In our reprehensions, pride has greater
share than good nature. We reprove not so
much in order to correct, as to intimate that
we hold ourselves free from such faiings.


Nothing is more rare than true good ma
ture. Many who imagine they possess it.,
naYe nothing more than a politeness and
case,


The rcsolute alone can be truly good ma
tured; those who commonly seem to be So,
are weak, and arc easily sourcd.


VIC seldom praise those heartily who
seem rot to admire rs,


When we seem to blaine ourselves, we
mean only 20 e.Stor. praise.


BY taking revenge man IS bnt even with
his enemy: but in passing it o1cr, he is snpe-
rior.

full articles.headline: FEBRUARY 22. le27
full articles.article:
the vlgilant but cautious measures of George
Norton insured them protection from the A.
mercans.


The report that had reused them from their
twilight revery, died away, but the sound
of coming troopers succeeded after a short
interval, and in a few minutes their tossing
plumes were seen dancing along the white
fences, and approaching the lonely cottage.
The old man threw down the bars that led
into the yard, and began to throw water in
to the long trough to supply their horses,
trembling all the while in suspense, whether
he was about to receive his bosom child, or
smooth his brow to smiling welcome of
men whose hands, for aught he knew,


might be weltering in his sons blood. The
| suspense was of momentary duration, the
first who approached him wore the uniform
of Briton, and his heart sunk within him
as he reached out his withered hand to
welcome him and assisted him in dismount-
ing.


! BY this time the whole corps was up, and
Roger recognized several of his old guests
among .hem. Some wounded soldiers were
carried to the barn, aud the officers, as soon
as their arrangements were completed with
out, accepted the apparently cordial invita-
! ton of the host to share the comforts of the


house; meantime, the table was spread and


decorated with the best the humble circum-
stances of the owner could afford. The Of
/ hcers were eight in number, all hardy, SOL
1 derly looking men, and, as they threw off


their heavy swords and caps, and crowded


round the hospitabe table, they resumed
the conversation it seemed they had lett Oft


when they first came up. "Well,' said the
Major, Il believe we determined upon all
| but the time and place of execution. -
"And that" replied sturdy fellow, on the
| other side, "s easily arranged; what say YOU


to farmer Norton's barn yard, and eight in
the morning. just by way of desert, besides,
| we shall save the rascal's break fast for some


better fellow" agreed. agreed, +" said they
all. The arrangements were thus made for
| the execution Of the prisoner, over hearty
meal and, when finished. a messenger was
despatched to inform him of his fate and bid


him prepare for it.


However i'll the members Of this little
family concealed their anxiety, in the mean
time, their agitation was not discovcred.--
The old man pretended to busy himself to
such degree as not to take notice of any
thing that passed, and Eliza left the room
determined to ascertain the worst, as the
suspense in which these proceedings involv-
cd her, was more cruel than the bitterest
reality could be. She soon found her saddest
fears were realized. Her husband was the
prisoner in whose blood they were to riot on
the morrow He was already wounded,
and was lying on some straw in bar
rack near the house, guarded by file OF
solders.


10 accomplish his rescue was now the de-
termined purpose OF her soul, though she
should sell her life in the attempt. She to K
her measures accordingly. She observed
the officer, who most resembled her in size,
and whose voice and manner she could easily
initiate and took measures to have him 'odg-
ed apart from his companions in little cor
ner room to which she could gain ready ac-
cess. She ascertained what was the coun-
tersgn, and having matured her design, re-
tired unsupported


At the dead hour OF the night, when all
was silent AS the grave, save now and then
the dull tramp of the sentinels was heard,
she stole into the young officers room and
carried off his clothes and sword Appar
elled i'll these, she passed the guard unsus-
pected, and penetrated into the prison of
her beloved and suffering husband. To ban
ish every shade of suspicion from the guard,
which walked around the barrack, assuming
the tone Of the officer she initiated, she ac-
costed the PROSTATE victim of revenge with
opprobious epi,hets, and asked him if his
neck was ready for the haltar-at the same
time endeavoring to make him understand
who she was. This unexpected intrusion
reused up the heroic American; he had re-
ceived his sentence, and had resolved to
bear it as soldier ought, for his wounds for
bid the hope of escape. But when he heard
the voice which too exactly initiated that of
his bitterest foe, his soul kindled to fame.
and sprnging from the ground he seized the
hilt of the sword which faint CLEAN of
moonlight revealed before him, drew it like
lightning from its scabbard, and plunged it
through Eiza's heart. She shrieked and
feil--while he, with one stroke, severing the
cords that bound him, leaped into the midst
of the guard, and three of them fell before
him ere his arm was paralyzed by death.
shot in the head killed him on the spot.


The camp was all alarm. A general rush
to the scene of blood succeeded, and the
cause was revealed. Even the wretches
who prosecuted theire discriminating warfare
with SO little mercy, wept over the heart
rending scene, and the aged parents were
left unmoested. The corpses were inferred
beneath green tree in the border of the
forest together, and the willow tree which
was planted by the grave, now spreads its
broad top wide over the unlettcred tomb
stone.


--------.-sr----


~

ceived that a man should suffer himself to
be overcome by the loss of child" These
reflections, however just-however philo-
sophical-tlid not console the father of Tul
liza; because, there are sorrows over which
reason has no power, and tears which time
alone can dry.


During my career of life, I have frequent
ly seen my companions fall by my side-my
brothers in arms-whose loss l have most
deeply deplored; but, in recalling to my
mind those ideas of glory, that hereditary
fame, which SO peculiarly endears the mem
cries of heroes who have fallen in the field of
honour, and rejecting that nothing was left
for me, but an infirm old age, and an obscure
grave, ! have frequently been tempted to
envy those whose names are immortalized
by their very deaths Every day takes from
me some old friend-some companion, of an
age equally advanced with myself regret
them, but without murmuring, in the words
of Montague, their lamp of life had burnt
to the socket; death is the immediate con-
sequence of protracted old age. But, when
young girl, just entering the portals of life
for whom heaven appears to have III store
a long series of happy years, on whom ma
ture has lavished all her most precious gifts


and whom birth and fortune have surround


ed with their most brilliant delusions--when


a being such as this is torn from the EN-.
braces of her mother, the hopes of her family,
and the expectations OF love, there is i'll this
cruel decree of fate, a kind of subvcrsion Of
the general laws of natlre--an assembage
OF contradictory circumstances, ldeaz and


cXpres ssions at which the senses sicken, and
the hearts break. Such is the event to which


| have alluded in the title of this article, and
ofwhch, during this short depression, have
rot lost sight.


/ Robertne de Nilarmont was the daughter
ofa brave companion in arms of the gallant


De Sufireen, who by twenty years nf glori-


GUS toll, had acquired an undoubted right to
enjoy in the bosom of his family, an ample
patrimonial estate, to which he has added lit


tle,or nothing by his services. He still rcckon-
ed among hisimpertlve duties, that of educat-


ing his son for the service of his country, and
ofbringing up his daughtcrto become the re-


ward of some young soldier, who, by
his name, his rank, and his merit should
show himself worthy OF such recompcnse.-
! | had known NJ. de Vilarmont in the East
| Indies.-A1uch Younger than ME, his father
had consigned him to my care; as to that of
a Mentor, and our relations of friendship
have never since been interrupted. 1t is
two years since accompanied him to Roch


etort, when he went thither to enter his son
as a midshipman, on the quarter deck of
vessel which he had himself commanded,
and at whose masthead the grandfather of
the young man had thirty years before,
! hosted the flag of vice-admiral. This reg
ular descent of glory, was good omen. and
/ accordingly our young Leon, as a reward
for gallant action, has already received the
decoration of the brave.


/ r., L.
reached her fifteenth year. Educated with
/ the tenderest care, under the eye of the
most af1'ectionate of mothers, she was alrea-


ly remarked as the model Of every rersec-
ton. 1t was the first season that the young
Robertine had appeared in the world; and all
eyes were turned upon her, and her delight


ed mother enjoyed, with too much con-
/ fidence. (why may | not say with too much
pride') the brilliant success which her
daughter met with at all concerts and balls,
of which she formed at once the principal
object ard the chief ornament. The birth


day of Mademoisel!c de Vlarnnnt had been
celebrated by brillilnt tete at the house of
her maternal grandfather, at which she had
made the deepest impression by the charms
Of her person, and the proofs which she had
given of the superiority Of her talents, which
her interesting modestv set off with double
I, splendour. Monsieurde Niarmont had been
prevented from accompanying the ladies,
whom he had, therefore entrusted to my
care; and during the whole continuance of
the ball, which encroached far into the morn
| ing, had ofliciated as gentleman N waiting
on the fair Robertine; I held her fan and her
iandk erchef while she danced; | led her
back to her place, and took particular care
to cover her with her shawl, as soon as the
country dance was concluded. ] was under
the same charm which had enchanted every
one around me. How suddenly and how
dreadfully was it to be dispelled 1t was
O'Clock when the party broke up-Rober-
tine had danced in the last set--her mother
wished that she should sit down little while
to cool herself; but with shawl, wrapping
cloak lined with fur, and a well closed car
riage, what danger, could possibly be ap
prehendetls On our going down stairs, the
coachmau was not with his horses; and
while the servants went in search of him,
we had to wait some minutes in freezing
hall, Gan inconvenience very general in Paris.
and from which even her palaces are not ex-
empt) Atlast the carriage drove up, Mad
anne de Nilarmont set me down at home, and
the lovely Robertine, in bidding me good
night, added, that she could not do without.
me, and that she retained me as her escort
to all the balls the next season. "lf am
alive" answered |, "but, next year is
Iop,r ,yb e., oil it~ IN l6pk
